3.1      Constraints set out or implicit in the scenario by key, domain, or relational algebra

 

By storing application logic at the database level, the integrity of WW’s business may be enforced by rules without losing the controls that support it formalised in predicate logic (Haan & Koppelaars, 2007, p. 127).  In that regard, where it cannot be acquired by structural definition, I will express the constraint in relational algebra as formulated by Codd (1970 ). 

 

3.1.1  Constraint one

 

(a) ‘It should not be possible for an employee to book two vehicles for the same day.’

 

Specific cardinality cannot be enforced entirely by relationships (Oppel, 2010, p. 215). It means, the ‘law of identity’, in respect to whether two vehicles is ‘exactly’, ‘at most’, or ‘at least’ two vehicles, needs validation. For instance, exactly two vehicles cannot be booked on the same day may be falsehood if WW user policy is no more than one vehicle. In which case, constraining at most one vehicle would equal not a least two vehicles (Hodges , 2001, p. 183):

 

.

 

 

(b)                Unique  

 

As Date affirms, if there were no elimination of duplicates from the output of a set operator, then the result could not be a relation (Date, 2013, p. 54). For instance if we project the Bookings relation onto the fourth attribute giving A the result is a single column that eliminates duplicate tuples:  

Bookings

BookingNo

EmployeeNo

RegistrationNo

Appr.

BookedOn_Date

A

BookedFor_Date

18-01-2018

 

Without having a ‘multiset’ (Makinson, 2008, p. 131), we cannot count the number of reoccurring dates according to PK RegistationNo. WW would need ‘unique quantification’ of days for the integrity of booking system so that one day is one and only one (Makinson, 2008, p. 2). I point the reader to the UNIQUE constraint already within the domain definition for Bookings (Employeenumber, BookedFor_Date) so that the ‘combination’ of these values are unique.   

 

 

3.1.2  Constraint two

 

(a) ‘Each booking is for one working day.’

 

This rule also gives the term ‘working day’ suggesting that weekend bookings are prohibited. Consequently, the constraint may be expressed ‘at most and at least’ one working day booking (Hodges , 2001, p. 184): ].

 

 

(b)   Check 

 

The constraint is embodied in the domain definition as a ‘check constraint’ using a DATENAME() Function that uses the parameter value Weekday. This enforces the predicate so that BookedFor_Date is verified against ‘Saturday’ and ‘Sunday’ which will fail as tuple inserts. Relational algebra does validate datatypes in one exclusive relation, but to the key and referential integrity constraints on relations (say R and S) giving    or  (Garcia-Molina, et al., 2009, pp. 58-62).

 

3.1.3  Constraint three

 

(a) ‘It should not be possible to book a service with a garage other than the one contracted for that vehicle.’

 

The cardinality between Garage and Vehicle is a contract, so the bond is established by formations: offer, acceptance, and intention (1869). While this civil formulae exists outside the system boundary, its binding effect may be imposed in the database schema as 1:n relationships as shown in the data model. This is to enable many vehicles to be booked if they have a contract with one and only one garage such that: ].

 

 

(b)                Difference

 

A vehicle that has more than one contracted garage in a service booking excluded:

 

Service (RegistrationNumber, GarageNumber, ServiceType)

Vehicle (RegistrationNumber, Make, Model, MOT_Date, ContractedServicer)

 

 

Enterprise constraint: ContractedGarage

 

A ß Project Service over RegstrationNumber, GarageNumber

 

B ß Project Vehicle over RegstrationNumber, ContractedServicer

 

A difference B is empty  

 

Testing the expression eliminates tuples where a vehicle has more than one contracted garage e.g. t = < (RegistrationNumber, OX67GKY) (GarageNumber, 567535) >

3.1.4  Constraint four

 

(a) ‘It should not be possible to book a vehicle if the MOT expires before or on the booking date.’

 

Bookings and Vehicle are two relations but the limitation expressed in the statement is not on their cardinality but through referential integrity ‘Date’ domain datatype. The function of the rule is a ‘process’ since it determines that the database should not insert a Booking tuple in a situation where BookingFor_Date is less than or equal to Mot_Date (Oppel, 2010, p. 215):  

 

 

(b) Difference

 

A booked date value for a vehicle inserted into relation Bookings is excluded where it is greater than the expiry MOT_Date value for the vehicle as follows:  

 

Bookings (BookingNumber, EmployeeNumber, RegistrationNumber, Approver, BookedFor_date, BookedOn_date, Certified)

Vehicle (RegistrationNumber, Make, Model, MOT_Date, ContractedServicer)

 

 

Enterprise constraint: expiryMOT 

 

A ß Booking join Vehicle /*over RegistrationNumber as a natural join*/

 

B ß Select A where BookedFor_Date < MOT_date /* A and B are horizontally quite long I indicate a cut line as dash - - -*/

 

A difference B is empty

 

 

For instance, the expression eliminates a violated business rule where t = < (EmployeeNumber, 1001) (BookedFor_Date, 15-03-2018)…(ContractedServicer) >

3.1.5  Constraint five

 

(a) ‘Bookings will need authorisation by a team leader.’

 

This business rule implies that a Bookings tuple will need to make reference to a tuple in the Employee relation where the attribute is Team_leader. For in the statement, every Employee.Team leader is the author of each Booking determined by the PK. This is as a dyadic constraint on fact defined in a binary relation (Hodges , 2001, p. 144) where:  [x is a Team_leader ∧  [y is a Booking → ­­­­x authorises y]].

 

 

Figure 3.1 Team leader authorisation graph

 

(b)Difference

 

An Employee, who is not a team leader, which attempts to approve another employee’s Bookings results in an insert failure according to an expression operated on the following relations:

 

Employee (EmployeeNumber, Name, TelephoneNumber, Category, Team_leader)

Bookings (BookingNumber, EmployeeNumber, RegistrationNumber, Approver, BookedFor_date, BookedOn_date, Certified)

 

 

Enterprise constraint: Team_leader authorisation

A ß project Bookings over Approver

B ß select from Employee where category = T

C ß project B over EmployeeNumber

A difference C is empty

 

For example, by referential constraint, the expression eliminates illegitimate approvers with a datatype category other than T from the Bookings relation in t = < (Approver, 1001) >

3.1.6  Constraint six

 

(a) A team leader cannot certify his own booking, and needs the authorisation of another team leader

 

The relationship R, ‘authorises’ - as between Team_leader  and Team_leader  - is ‘irreflexive’ given that it is falsehood that a Team_leader in a given tuple set A may authorises themselves (Hodges , 2001, p. 146): Note that while the possessive determiner ‘his’ is gender oriented, the Employee relvar includes no data validation rules for females and males (cf. ISO/IEC 5218 (2004)).  However, the scenario also stipulates authorisation between team leaders is off-line on trust. This means that the constraint should be applied where an ‘employee’ cannot certify their own booking. 

 

 

Figure 3.2 Irreflexive graph – Employee booking certification

 

(b)                Difference

 

An insert made by an employee to certify their own booking will be fail as follows:

 

Bookings (BookingNumber, EmployeeNumber, RegistrationNumber, Approver, BookedFor_date, BookedOn_date, Certified)

Employee (EmployeeNumber, Name, TelephoneNumber, Category, Team_leader)

 

 

Enterprise constraint: Self-certification

A ß Booking join Employee

B ß Select A where Employee number ≠ Approver

A difference B is empty

 

For example, expressing the constraint algebraically may give a Boolean difference to eliminate t = < (EmployeeNumber, 2034) (Approver, 2034) >
